description: It also normalizes the normal vector in get_sph_theta (since arccos only accepts values between -1.0 and 1.0).. Some dataobjects (particularly custom ones) do not have a normalized normal vector.. Likewise this is also convenient if you wish to use this for other routines/methods etc.
title: [BUGFIX] normalise all normal vectors in functions that take a normal vector (for e.g get_sph_theta)

pullrequest.title: [BUGFIX] normalise all normal vectors in functions that take a normal vector (for e.g get_sph_theta)

content.raw: It was because if the vector is not normalized, then the function returns NaN due to the arccos function. Particle in memory datasets do not seem to normise the normal vector with a dataobject. Either way I will post an example later today/tonight
content.html: It was because if the vector is not normalized, then the function returns NaN due to the arccos function. Particle in memory datasets do not seem to normise the normal vector with a dataobject. Either way I will post an example later today/tonight

pullrequest.title: [BUGFIX] normalise all normal vectors in functions that take a normal vector (for e.g get_sph_theta)

content.raw:
Yeah, to further explain.

if object.get_field_parameter("normal") != normalized.. or is in units that are not normalised (e.g "cm" rather than "code_length" if you choose your objects code units to be "cm" which can be the case in loading in memory particle data sets)... then e.g this function will return the wrong result (i.e out of a factor of 1e22 or something if you are using e.g "cm" as your code length)

Yes, I think other functions that rely on a normal vector should also check if the normal vector is being normalized to be internally consistent... and so that the end user does not have to worry about making that addition step (maybe have a routine that checks/normalises the normal vector within math_utils.py
content.html:
Yeah, to further explain.

if object.get_field_parameter("normal") != normalized.. or is in units that are not normalised (e.g "cm" rather than "code_length" if you choose your objects code units to be "cm" which can be the case in loading in memory particle data sets)... then e.g this function will return the wrong result (i.e out of a factor of 1e22 or something if you are using e.g "cm" as your code length)

Yes, I think other functions that rely on a normal vector should also check if the normal vector is being normalized to be internally consistent... and so that the end user does not have to worry about making that addition step (maybe have a routine that checks/normalises the normal vector within math_utils.py

pullrequest.title: [BUGFIX] normalise all normal vectors in functions that take a normal vector (for e.g get_sph_theta)

content.raw:
Without the ``axis`` keyword, the ``numpy.linalg.norm`` function assumes the argument is a single vector or matrix and will always return a scalar value.  I don't think there's any reason to convert it into an array.  Additionally, a vector norm will be zero if and only if every component of the vector is 0.  So, rather than setting L2 to 1 in that case, you can just have something like:

```
#!python

if L2 == 0:
    return vector
return vector / L2

```
content.html:
Without the axis keyword, the numpy.linalg.norm function assumes the argument is a single vector or matrix and will always return a scalar value. I don't think there's any reason to convert it into an array. Additionally, a vector norm will be zero if and only if every component of the vector is 0. So, rather than setting L2 to 1 in that case, you can just have something like:

if L2 == 0:
    return vector
return vector / L2
